powerHaDeX 1.0

    • Simulation - example usage

    Simulation - example usage

    Example_simulation.Rmd
    library(powerHDX)
library(ggplot2)

    Using the simulation implemented in the package powerHDX noisy deuteration curves can be generated. Let us consider an example peptide PPVQ. The function simulate_theoretical_spectra is used to obtain mass spectra for given exposure times provided as times as follows:

    times <- c(5, 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 60, 100, 300, 500, 900, 1200, 1500, 1800)
set.seed(17)

spectra <- simulate_theoretical_spectra(sequence = "PPVQ",
                                        charge = 4,
                                        protection_factor = 100,
                                        times = times,
                                        pH = 7.5,
                                        temperature = 15,
                                        n_molecules = 500,
                                        time_step_const = 1,
                                        use_markov = TRUE)

head(spectra)
#>    Exposure  PH    Intensity      Mz Charge Sequence  PF
#> 1:        0 7.5 0.7774507202 110.818      4     PPVQ 100
#> 2:        0 7.5 0.1887326538 110.818      4     PPVQ 100
#> 3:        0 7.5 0.0298879909 110.818      4     PPVQ 100
#> 4:        0 7.5 0.0035555122 110.818      4     PPVQ 100
#> 5:        0 7.5 0.0003430289 110.818      4     PPVQ 100
#> 6:        5 7.5 0.7541498940 110.818      4     PPVQ 100

    Simulated spectrum for particular time can be visualized using powerHDX as follows

    plot_single_spectrum(spectra, 30)

    plot_single_spectrum(spectra, 300)

    Deuteration curve for such theoretical spectra is calculated via get_deuteration_curve_single_spectrum:

    one_curve <- get_deuteration_curve_single_spectrum(spectra)
one_curve
#>     Exposure  PH Charge Sequence  PF     Mass
#>  1:        0 7.5      4     PPVQ 100 439.2431
#>  2:        5 7.5      4     PPVQ 100 439.5354
#>  3:       10 7.5      4     PPVQ 100 439.5615
#>  4:       20 7.5      4     PPVQ 100 439.6158
#>  5:       30 7.5      4     PPVQ 100 439.6499
#>  6:       40 7.5      4     PPVQ 100 439.6981
#>  7:       50 7.5      4     PPVQ 100 439.7306
#>  8:       60 7.5      4     PPVQ 100 439.7749
#>  9:      100 7.5      4     PPVQ 100 439.7608
#> 10:      300 7.5      4     PPVQ 100 439.8695
#> 11:      500 7.5      4     PPVQ 100 439.8272
#> 12:      900 7.5      4     PPVQ 100 439.8272
#> 13:     1200 7.5      4     PPVQ 100 439.8494
#> 14:     1500 7.5      4     PPVQ 100 439.8715
#> 15:     1800 7.5      4     PPVQ 100 439.8655

ggplot(one_curve, aes(x = Exposure, y = Mass)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_line()

    Noisy curves are generated via get_noisy_deuteration_curves. The number of technical replicates among which uncertainty can be calculated is n_runs and the number of noisy curves is n_replicates.

    get_noisy_deuteration_curves(spectra, 
                             n_runs = 2,
                             n_replicates = 3,
                             compare_pairs = FALSE)
